awd_titl_txt: EAGER:  Collaborative:  Leveraging High-Density Internet Peering Hubs to Mitigate Large-Scale DDoS Attacks
awd_abstract_narration:
Large-scale distributed denial of service (DDoS) attacks pose an imminent threat to the availability of critical Internet-based operations, as demonstrated by recent incidents that brought down a number of highly popular web services such as Twitter, Spotify and Reddit. While several solutions to counter DDoS attacks have been proposed by both industry and academia, most of the solutions that are currently deployed on the Internet - such as traffic scrubbing - tend to detect and mitigate DDoS attacks close to the victim edge network, once the attack has already caused damage. Creating systems for early DDoS attack detection and mitigation that can be deployed at the core of the Internet has the potential to significantly improve Internet security and reliability. 

This project investigates innovative machine learning-based DDoS attack detection and mitigation solutions that can be deployed at the core of the Internet, within Internet eXchange Points (IXPs). IXPs are high-density peering hubs that provide infrastructure used by autonomous systems (ASes) to interconnect, and are therefore well positioned to observe significant fractions of global Internet traffic. The project leverages IXP-based traffic monitoring to develop advanced traffic analysis and classification methods for efficient, automated early detection and mitigation of DDoS attacks. The researchers aim to first investigate methods for defending against distributed reflective DoS (DRDoS) attacks, which rely on spoofed IP traffic to amplify the attacker's available bandwidth, and to then expand the investigation to volumetric DDoS attacks that do not rely on spoofed traffic. As part of the project, the researchers aim to develop collaborations with IXPs and Internet operators around the world, to facilitate research on DDoS defenses and increase opportunities for high-impact technology transfer.

por.por_cntn:
Large-scale distributed denial of service (DDoS) attacks pose an imminent threat to the availability of critical Internet-based operations. While several solutions to counter DDoS attacks have been proposed by both industry and academia, most of the solutions that are currently deployed on the Internet - such as traffic scrubbing - tend to detect and mitigate DDoS attacks close to the victim edge network, once the attack has already caused damage. An important goal of this project was to create a system for early DDoS attack detection and mitigation that can be deployed at the core of the Internet to significantly improve Internet security and reliability.

During the first part of this project, the research team formed a collaboration with two Internet eXchange Points (IXPs), one based in the United States and one based in Europe. These collaborations allowed the researchers to gain significant knowledge on how US and European IXPs operate in practice. During the second part of the project, based on the acquired operational knowledge, the researchers developed an open-source system called IXmon for detecting DDoS attacks that leverage vulnerable UDP services to reflect and amplify attack traffic. The IXmon system was then used to monitor traffic from the US-based IXP collaborator and was able to detect close to 1,000 DDoS attacks over a period of about two years. An analysis of these findings revealed what protocols and services are most commonly abused to launch UDP-based DDoS attacks and how many networks attackers typically leverage and abuse to amplify their attack traffic. In addition, the project showed that currently available DDoS defenses based on the BGP protocol are rarely utilized in response to such attacks, unless the attack has very high volume and lasts for prolonged intervals of time. This is likely due to the fact that such defenses are still typically manually triggered, and thus response to attacks is slow and costly.

The IXmon system developed during this project has been released on GitHub (https://github.com/perdisci/IXmon). IXmon could be used by IXPs around the world to automate DDoS attack detection to more rapidly and effectively mitigate DDoS attacks. A description of the system has been published at the DIMVA 2021 conference. A presentation of the related academic paper publication can also be found on Youtube (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rO1r2kjO1Q0).
